items.title: fix(html/element/li) full title

items.content_html:
A minor change. When the article covers the main tools (that have the screenshots such as Web Console and JavaScript Debugger) I noticed that the description for that tool is after the screenshot. The usability issues with this are:
(1) When a newish user see's the screenshot they won't really know what they are looking at until they look at the text after the screenshot.
(2) It is unclear, at first, if the descriptive text belongs to the screenshot below or after the text.

I just copied and pasted the descriptive text (in the

tag) from the bottom of the image to the top of the image right under the title. You should find that more users will understand immediately what they are look at when they can read the descriptive text right before starring at the image. If anything the descriptive text can remind some users what the panel is for so they remember what they are looking at.

Summary

Motivation

Supporting details

Related issues

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Update Firefox Dev Tools - Minor Text Change

items.content_html:
Preparation for this is all listed in #9218.

The conversion report summary:

## All unhandled elements
- tr (799)
- th[scope="row"] (457)
- td (312)
- table (231)
- td[style="text-align: center; background-color: rgb(255, 153, 153); vertical-align: top;"] (158)
- th[scope="row"][style="white-space: nowrap; vertical-align: top;"] (156)
- td[style="text-align: center; background-color: rgb(204, 255, 102); vertical-align: top;"] (119)
- kbd (117)
- td[style="text-align: center; vertical-align: top;"] (92)
- td[style="text-align: center; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 102); vertical-align: top;"] (73)
- th[scope="row"][style="vertical-align: top;"] (65)
- th[colSpan="4"][scope="col"] (39)
- th[scope="col"][style="text-align: center;"] (26)
- table.standard-table (21)
- table.standard-table.no-markdown (14)
- td[rowSpan="3"] (6)
- th[scope="col"] (5)
- table.no-markdown (2)
- table.standard-table["] (1)
- th[colSpan="2"][scope="col"] (1)
- td[colSpan="3"] (1)
- td[colSpan="2"] (1)
- td#a-example (1)
- td#img-example (1)
- td#span-example (1)
- td#em-example (1)
- td#i-example (1)
- td#b-example (1)
- td#strong-example (1)
- td#mark-example (1)
- td#s-example (1)
- td#sub-example (1)
- td#small-example (1)
- td#address-example (1)
- td#cite-example (1)
- td#sup-example (1)
- td#q-example (1)
- td#br-example (1)
- td#wbr-example (1)
- td#time-example (1)
- td#code-example (1)
- td#audio-example (1)
- td#video-example (1)
- td#p-example (1)
- td#blockquote-example (1)
- td#details-example (1)
- td#ul-example (1)
- td#ol-example (1)
- td#dl-example (1)
- td#hr-example (1)
- td#h1-h6-example (1)
- span[lang="fr"] (1)
- span[lang="ja"] (1)
- th[colSpan="3"][scope="colgroup"] (1)
- th[colSpan="2"][scope="colgroup"] (1)
- th[rowSpan="3"][scope="rowgroup"] (1)
- th[rowSpan="2"][scope="rowgroup"] (1)

(the full report: https://gist.github.com/wbamberg/e0dbf100125e265d0e4c1fc8635259a0)

Most of the unconverted elements are from unconverted tables, which are discussed in #9218 (comment). Other things in here:

  • unconverted <kbd> elements, which here as previously we're keeping as HTML
  • all the td# items are for live samples in the tables at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Cheatsheet
  • span[lang="fr"] and span[lang="ja"] are for the list of different date styles in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Introduction_to_HTML/Advanced_text_formatting#marking_up_times_and_dates, and seemed worth keeping to me

  • ommitted the aria/aria_techniques section, since that needs a lot of editing.
  • omittied the aria/Roles as that is in a different PR
  • ommitted a few files that I will be deleting; so no need to create a md file for them. (deleting files will be a different PR)

‚ùì Why?
Because. That's why!
And, because it's what we do.

items.content_html:
Summary

Fix the note in the Meaning column for character ^ which says:

This character has a different meaning when it appears at the start of a group.

to say

This character has a different meaning when it appears at the start of a range.

Motivation

I am unable to find any difference in meaning when ^ is used in a group,
at the start or otherwise. It does differ when used in a range.

Supporting details

I am unable to find anything in ECMA 262 22.2 RegExp (Regular Expression) Objects (particularly 22.2.2.6 Assertion) which indicates that the behavior of ^ differs inside and outside a group.

console.assert(/^H/.test('Hi') === /(^H)/.test('Hi'));
console.assert(/^H/.test('hi') === /(^H)/.test('hi'));

I suspect this note is referring to the different behavior when used in a
CharacterClass, referred to as a range elsewhere in the docs, where it denotes inverting the class/range. This is also discussed in the "Different meaning of '?!' combination usage in Assertions and Ranges" section of the same file.

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error

Thanks for considering,
Kevin
items.title: RegExp Assertions: fix note about ^ in group

items.content_html:
This PR contains miscellaneous fixes to make Games convertible to Markdown:

  • mostly removing inline styles
  • a couple of live samples
  • removing some random <audio> elements
  • suppress conversion for a couple of tables

After this PR the conversion report for Games lists the following as unconvertible:

## All unhandled elements
- kbd (25)
- sub (13)
- tr (8)
- th[scope="row"] (7)
- td (3)
- table.no-markdown.standard-table (2)
- table.standard-table (2)
  • all four tables here will stay as HTML, 2 because they are unconvertible and 2 because they are too wide
  • <sub> is used only in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Games/Techniques/3D_collision_detection#point_vs._aabb, where it seemed best to keep it.

So after this PR the next one will be the conversion PR itself.
items.title: [Markdown] [Games] Miscellaneous fixes for Games

items.content_html:
Mention the 5-second default value, and remove mention of the invalid -1 value.

Motivation

Accurately represent specifications and browser behavior.

Supporting details

  • Definition of Access-Control-Max-Age: https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#http-new-header-syntax
  • Definition of the value syntax: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7234#section-1.2.1
  • Chromium implementation as an unsigned integer: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:services/network/public/cpp/cors/preflight_result.cc;l=49;drc=49e7c0b4886cac1f3d09dc046bd528c9c811a0fa

Related issues

n/a

items.title: CORS: Align Access-Control-Max-Age documentation with specs

items.content_html:
This is part of update for FF94 in #9366

The API has the following changes w.r.t. current docs (by inspection and testing)

  • Sanitizer.getConfiguration()
  • Sanitizer.sanitizeToString() method removed.
  • Element.setHTML() method added.
  • Some new configuration options, but these are still not actually supported anywhere.

There is still a fair bit to do so putting in draft for now.
spec is key resource, as is github repo and setHTML pr
items.title: FF94 : Updates to sanitizer API

items.content_html:
Fixes #9170

Code inspection shows that AV1 is only disabled on a small subset OS/hardware. This clarifies and links to bug for remaining part. Many thanks to @jwatt
items.title: FF supports AV1 but not on android and windows on ARM

npx prettier --write ./files/en-us/web/javascript

Just an experiment to see if we might want to do this.
